timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            Format specifier `F` will be working similar to format specifier `f`.
          
          
            
            It represents the most significant digit of the seconds fraction and all trailing `0` s will be printed to meet the number of `F` s in the pattern,
          
          
            
            e.g.: for a time part `10:20:30.1234` and pattern `HH:mm:ss.FFFFFF`, the output string of the function would be: `10:20:30.123400`.
          
          
            
            Diverging from the reference documentation, format specifier `F` behaves identical to format specifier `f`.
          
      
    
    
  

IMO the docs for f should explain sufficiently F's behavior, we shouldn't need an extra example.
But stepping back, if f==F, why do we need F at all? @matriv, do we want to plug into some SQL Server's FORMAT usages? Otherwise I guess it could be dropped altogether.

timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -721,6 +721,53 @@ include-tagged::{sql-specs}/docs/docs.csv-spec[truncateIntervalHour]
 include-tagged::{sql-specs}/docs/docs.csv-spec[truncateIntervalDay]
 --------------------------------------------------
 
+[[sql-functions-datetime-format]]
+==== `FORMAT`
+
+.Synopsis:
+[source, sql]
+--------------------------------------------------
+FORMAT(
+    date_exp/datetime_exp/time_exp, <1>
+    string_exp) <2>
+--------------------------------------------------
+
+*Input*:
+
+<1> date/datetime/time expression
+<2> format pattern
+
+*Output*: string
+
+*Description*: Returns the date/datetime/time as a string using the format specified in the 2nd argument. The formatting
+pattern used is the one from
+https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/t-sql/functions/format-transact-sql?view=sql-server-ver15#ExampleD[Microsoft SQL Server Format Specification].
+If any of the two arguments is `null` or the pattern is an empty string `null` is returned.
+
+[NOTE]
+If the 1st argument is of type `time`, then pattern specified by the 2nd argument cannot contain date related units
+(e.g. 'dd', 'MM', 'YYYY', etc.). If it contains such units an error is returned.
+
+[NOTE]
+Format specifier `F` will be working similar to format specifier `f`.
+It represents the most significant digit of the seconds fraction and all trailing `0` s will be printed to meet the number of `F` s in the pattern,
+e.g.: for a time part `10:20:30.1234` and pattern `HH:mm:ss.FFFFFF`, the output string of the function would be: `10:20:30.123400`.

I think there are some unit tests missing, regarding the various patterns.

m - The minute, from 0 through 59
M - The month, from 1 through 12
h - The hour, using a 12-hour clock from 1 to 12
H - The hour, using a 24-hour clock from 0 to 23
d - The day of the month, from 1 through 31
MMM
MMMM
s
other flavors of the year formatting (y, yy, yyy, yyyyy)
other flavors of z (zz, zzz)
also, special handling situations: %, \, any string literal.
maybe others I missed.

If we don't plan on supporting any of the above, at least take them out from the docs, because as the docs read now, we support patterns according  with https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/base-types/custom-date-and-time-format-strings.
